title: What is creative writing in general? How do writers be creative with their writing style? - An Inkling of Writers - Quora

response.answer_text: Becoming a creative writer - that is, a writer who is creative - is actually pretty simple. But it’s not easy. First, you have to read, and you have to read a lot. It also helps if you read a wide variety of books: find a genre or two (or three, or four) that you’re interested in and go nuts. Find a couple favourite authors and dive into their bibliographies. This will help you get a good feel for what’s been done before. Next, you have to write a lot, and you have to accept that, when you first start writing, you won’t be very good. In fact, you’ll be downright awful. But this is OK. No writer’s first story has ever been a masterpiece. After that, you have to accept that you’ll never become a “good” writer. There will always be something you can improve; the trick is getting your writing to that sweet spot where it’s polished enough that other people will want to read it. It takes experience to know where that sweet spot is, and even the most experienced writers often can’t see it. You’ll also need to develop a thick skin. Criticism is one of the best things that can happen to a writer (so long as it’s sincere). It’ll hurt your ego for a little while, but given time you’ll grow from it. If you’re serious about becoming a writer, your work is going to get rejected a lot: you’ll soon discover that a rejection with criticisms is far, far better than silence (or, even worse, the dreaded form letter). And the last, and maybe most important thing is: don’t worry about being creative. Just write what you want to write. It’s not “creativity” that makes a good writer; it’s practice, practice, practice. Do this, and eventually you’ll find yourself naturally developing your own style. But don’t worry too much about being “creative”: you can write nothing but Harry Potter fan fiction and still be “creative.” Originality doesn’t necessarily spawn creativity. Have fun!

Creative writing. Creative writing is any writing that goes outside the bounds of normal professional, journalistic, academic, or technical forms of literature, typically identified by an emphasis on narrative craft, character development, and the use of literary tropes or with various traditions of poetry and poetics.
